title: How to Do a Coconut Oil Hair Mask

parts.name: Making the Nourishing Coconut Oil Hair Mask

steps.headline: Warm up 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of coconut oil if it’s in a solid form.
steps.description: Coconut oil has a really low melting temperature of 76 °F (24 °C), so it doesn’t take much at all to melt it down. Put 1 tablespoon (15 mL) into a microwave-safe bowl and heat it up for 15 seconds. Getting the coconut oil into a liquid state will make it much easier to combine with the other ingredients.

steps.headline: Separate the egg if you want to use just the whites or just the yolks.
steps.description: The yolks will provide extra moisture, and the whites will provide more protein. You can use either part or both parts for your mask!How to Separate an Egg: Crack the egg open on the edge of a clean bowl. Hold the egg upright over the bowl and remove the top half of the shell; pass the yolk back and forth between the two shell halves and let the white part drop into the bowl below.

steps.headline: Mix together the coconut oil, olive oil, honey, and egg in a small bowl.
steps.description: Use 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of coconut oil, 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of olive oil, ⁄2 tablespoon (7.4 mL) of honey, and 1 large egg (separated or whole). Whisk everything together until it has all completely combined. If your hair is exceptionally long or thick, double the recipe.

steps.headline: Add 1/2 of a ripe avocado to your mask if your hair is really dry.
steps.description: Avocado is full of lots of great, healthy fats. It’ll add a boost of moisturizing power to your mask, plus it’s a great way to use up leftover avocado. Simply spoon out half of an avocado into a bowl and mash it up before combining it with the rest of your ingredients. Adding avocado to your diet is also a great way to nourish your hair from the inside out.

steps.headline: Include 1/2 of a ripe banana if your hair tends to be on the frizzy side.
steps.description: Put half of a peeled banana into a small bowl and use a fork to mash it up. Once it has been mashed, go ahead and combine it with the rest of your mask ingredients. Banana is a simple moisturizing element that you may already have at home.

steps.headline: Incorporate a few drops of essential oils for an aromatic effect.
steps.description: Rosemary is said to promote hair growth, lavender can help soothe an irritated scalp, cedar wood is good for dandruff, and sandalwood is supposed to help prevent hair loss. 4 to 5 drops of a single essential oil will be enough to infuse your mask with a lovely scent. Avoid ingesting essential oils, as some of them could make you ill. Essential oils are highly concentrated, so avoid using more than the recommended amount.

parts.name: Putting the Mask on Your Hair

steps.headline: Dampen your hair first if you have thick or tangled hair.
steps.description: It can be hard to really saturate thick, tangled, or curly hair with the mask. You could mist your hair with a spray bottle or simply run water from the faucet or shower over your hair for 15 to 30 seconds. You can gently brush through it afterward or let the mask itself do the detangling for you. If your hair is straight and easy to comb through, there’s no need to get your hair wet first.

steps.headline: Section your hair so you can evenly apply the mask.
steps.description: Gather the top 1/3 of your hair on top of your head with a hair clip. Gather the middle section of hair and secure it with another hair clip. Leave the bottom 1/3 of your hair down—this will be the first layer you apply the mask to. If you have really thick hair, you may even want to separate your hair into 4 or 5 layers.

steps.headline: Apply the mask to each section using your fingertips.
steps.description: Dip your fingers into the mask and scoop out a small amount, about ⁄2 tablespoon (7.4 mL) or so. Start applying the mask at your roots and work your way down through the middle shafts, all the way to the ends of your hair. Massage the oil into your scalp. Do the bottom section of hair first, then the middle section, and end with the top section of hair. This can get a little messy, so put a towel around your shoulders or wear an old T-shirt. If needed, you could even use a comb to help distribute the mask and work out tangles.

steps.headline: Put a shower cap or towel on your hair to keep the mask from dripping.
steps.description: This will also help keep the mask on your hair and off of your shoulders or the furniture. If it helps, clip all your hair on top of your head first, and then wrap the towel around it or put on the shower cap.Tip: For an extra hydrating boost, run a hair dryer on low over your wrapped hair for a couple of minutes. The warmth will help open up your hair cuticles so it can absorb the mask even more.

steps.headline: Let the mask saturate your hair for 15 to 20 minutes.
steps.description: Set a timer and sit back and relax. You could clean up the ingredients from making the mask, or take the opportunity to do some other self-care tasks, like applying a face mask or painting your nails. You can leave the mask on for up to an hour, but any more than that and you risk the egg starting to dry out, which would make it a lot harder to rinse away.

parts.name: Rinsing out with the Removal Mask

steps.headline: Make a removal mask out of a raw egg and warm water.
steps.description: Coconut oil can be difficult to wash out of hair—it’s thick and slick and usually needs more than a simple shampoo. In a small bowl, whisk together a raw egg and about ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of warm water. Keep whisking the mixture until the egg and water are completely incorporated.Tip: Avoid using hot water for this task. Really hot water could actually start to cook the egg, which is definitely not what you want to do.

steps.headline: Apply the removal mask to your hair to help rinse away the oil.
steps.description: Unwrap your hair from the towel or remove the shower cap. Because this next part is a little messy, try doing it over a sink or while standing in the shower. Slowly pour the removal mask over your hair and use your hands to work it through your locks as best you can. Egg cuts through oil and grease and will help remove the buildup from all those good moisturizing agents you used.

steps.headline: Wrap your hair back up and set a timer for 5 to 10 minutes.
steps.description: Rewrap your hair in a towel or put your shower cap back on. If there is egg wash running down your neck, wipe it away with a damp cloth so that it doesn’t dry on your skin. Let the mask saturate the oil so it’ll be easier to wash off. Avoid leaving the egg wash in your hair for more than 15 minutes maximum, as it’ll start to dry after that amount of time.

steps.headline: Rinse out the mask with cool to warm water.
steps.description: You don’t have to wash your hair with shampoo after using a coconut oil hair mask, though you can if you want to. Simply rinsing away the removal mask and coconut oil mask with water is usually enough to clear it away and leave you with shiny, smooth hair. Take your time with this part of the process. It may take 5 to 10 minutes to really rinse everything away. Give extra attention to your scalp so that sections of oil aren’t left behind.

steps.headline: Let your hair air dry to avoid drying it out or damaging it further.
steps.description: Pat your hair with an old cotton T-shirt or a microfiber towel to remove excess water. Gently squeeze out your hair in sections instead of rubbing a towel back and forth. Then let it dry naturally before you style it. If you do need to blow dry your hair, try using the lowest heat setting instead of the highest.

steps.headline: Use a hair mask once per week to maintain shiny, healthy hair.
steps.description: You can repeat this process regularly to promote your hair’s health. Most of the ingredients are probably already in your home, and you can experiment with adding in different ingredients to see what you like best. If you swim in chlorinated water or spend a lot of time in the sun, you could even use this mask every time you wash your hair. If you have thin or oily hair, you most likely won’t need to use this mask as often. Twice or once a month will probably be enough. If your hair feels greasy to the touch after using the mask, decrease how often you’re applying it.
